meeting_annotations.speaker: Peter Driscoll (Carnegie Science)
meeting_annotations.transcript: in a modeling way that you don't do it in the lab, you just do it numerically. And if you can't, what are the limitations to not why why can't you do it?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Laurie Barge (NASA JPL)
meeting_annotations.transcript: The limitations we've had as told to me by the modeling collaborators are that the big molecules I want to work with don't have all the thermodynamic data of some of the small molecules. So then he has to like derive it from the molecule and this takes them a really long time. And then the other issue was it was equilibrium modeling and our experiments not in equilibrium. And also the modeling would tell us stability of a product at a condition, but it didn't take into account the instability of the molecule, like we were talking about. And so there was nowhere in the model to input the fact that like this molecule degrades at a well known exponential curve that we see in the lab, but that's not included in the model. So it was I didn't realize it would be this challenging.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dimitar Sasselov
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, when I started this Laurie, I had the same naive expectation that we could do everything in the computer coming from computer simulations and they disabused me very quickly of that.

meeting_annotations.transcript: [laughter]

meeting_annotations.speaker: Aaron Engelhart - U of MN
meeting_annotations.transcript: silicates and it does it reversibly and we're kind of excited about it because it seems like that could be kind of a way to do compartmentalization because these lipid assemblies don't really work very well at high salt.
